newsitem.title: USA: OPTIONS - Dlr/mark decline buoys front end vols.
newsitem.headline: OPTIONS - Dlr/mark decline buoys front end vols.

text.p: Implied volatilities for dollar/mark options, particularly the shorter dates, blipped up in U.S. trading as the market was caught off guard by the greenback's sharp slide below 1.6750 marks, dealers said.

They noted that many traders had become short gamma and short downside strikes lately because of a widely held view that the dollar's recent decline from February highs above 1.72 marks was just a correction of its two-year-long uptrend that had accelerated in the early part of the year.
"The market was not expecting the dollar collapsing, that fast anyway," said a U.S. bank trader in California.
Implied volatility for one-month dollar/mark rose to 9.65/9.85 percent, up a quarter point from European midsession levels and half a point from late Monday levels.

One-week jumped a full point from European levels to 9.5/10.5 percent as the dollar plunged through 1.6800 marks and 1.6750 marks without a significant rebound. On the other hand, the back end was lagging, with one-year volatility at 9.75/9.95 percent, up 0.2 point.
"The market's been favoring mark puts pretty much since the beginning of the year, so we had a lot of people short the downside of the dollar," the California trader added.
Risk-reversals, which reflect pricing differentials between puts and calls, were turning in favor of mark calls, at least at the front end.
One-month 25-delta dollar/mark stood at 0.1/0.3 percent bid for mark calls against around par in late Monday trade.
A U.S. bank trader in Chicago said a fall in dollar/Swiss franc after a recent technical break below a rising trendline in the 1.45 to 1.46-franc area led the way down for dollar/mark.
"Dollar/Swiss usually leads the way whether on the upside or the downside," he noted.
"When you have to call into question is when you have a big move in dollar/mark and dollar/Swiss isn't quite following...but in this case, it's definitely a dollar move to the downside," he added.
One-month dollar/Swiss volatility rose to 11.0/11.3 percent from Monday's 10.6/10.9.
Dollar/yen volatilities were also slightly firmer despite a relatively narrow range-trading in spot.
Traders said volatilities inched up in sympathy to dollar/mark amid a generally nervous environment ahead of the March 25 Federal Open Market Committee meeting.
The dollar gradually eroded from overnight highs near 124 yen but stayed above 122 yen, still well clear of critical support and resistance levels at 120 and 125 yen.
"At this point, we're pretty much in the middle of the range," the California trader said. "It's not like we're endangering any strong support levels."
One-month dollar/yen volatility rose 0.2 point to 9.8/10.0 percent, while one-month gained half a point to 8.7/9.7.
One-month 25-delta risk reversal, which had briefly flipped toward yen puts late last week, was back in favor of yen calls at 0.0/0.3 percent.
